explanations.A: Even numbers can be written as two of the same number added together. 3 + 3 = 6 shows this.
explanations.B: I think you have looked at the number of rows. 2 + 2 = 4, but we need 6.
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the number of rows from 6. 4 + 4 = 8, but we need two of the same number to add to make 6.
explanations.D: I think you have given the total number of counters, but we need two of the same number to add to make 6.

explanations.A: I think you have looked at the number of rows. 2 + 2 = 4, but we need 12.
explanations.B: Even numbers can be written as two of the same number added together. 6 + 6 = 12 shows this.
explanations.C: I think you have subtracted the number of rows from 12. 10 + 10 = 20 but we need two of the same number to add to make 12.
explanations.D: I think you have given the total number of counters, but we need two of the same number to add to make 12.

explanations.A: You may have selected this as 8 is even, but will the two numbers add to give an even total?
explanations.B: You may have selected this as it starts with an even number, but will the two numbers add to give an even total?
explanations.C: 7 + 7 = 14, which is even. Whenever you add two of the same number together, you get an even number.
explanations.D: I think you have confused even and odd. The evens are in the 2 times table.

explanations.A: I think you may be confusing the counters given out already with the total number of counters. Try imagining that 10 counters have been given out already (an even amount as everyone gets 2 each), would the left over counters make this up to an even or odd number? What if it was another even number of counters that have already been given out?
explanations.B: We are able to work it out without collecting in the counters. Try imagining that 10 counters have been given out already (an even amount as everyone gets 2 each), would the left over counters make this up to an even or odd number? What if it was another even number of counters that have already been given out?
explanations.C: The counters were given out in 2s, so each person is one extra column of counters on the diagram. Not matter how many extra columns we add, there will still be that extra 1 on the end, so it's an odd number of counters.
explanations.D: We are able to work it out without knowing the number of students. Try imagining that 10 counters have been given out already (an even amount as everyone gets 2 each), would the left over counters make this up to an even or odd number? What if it was another even number of counters that have already been given out?

explanations.A: You may think it's odd because there are an odd number of blocks in each row. Try thinking about it as columns. Each person got one column of blocks (2 blocks) and we have complete columns of 2 left. What does this tell us?
explanations.B: We are able to work it out without knowing the number of students. Try imagining that 10 blocks have been given out already (an even amount as everyone gets 2 each), would the left over blocks make this up to an even or odd number? What if it was another even number of blocks that have already been given out?
explanations.C: The blocks were given out in 2s, so each person is one extra column of counters on the diagram. No matter how many extra columns we add, there will be full columns of 2, so it is even.
explanations.D: We are able to work it out without collecting in the blocks. Try imagining that 10 blocks have been given out already (an even amount as everyone gets 2 each), would the left over blocks make this up to an even or odd number? What if it was another even number of blocks that have already been given out?
